Award.AbstractNarration:
Calcium-dependent synaptic neurotransmitter release is the primary means of communication between neurons in the central and peripheral nervous systems, including the mammalian brain. It is triggered by the entry of calcium ions into the cell, followed by their diffusion and binding to calcium-sensing proteins. This fundamental physiological cell process is called secretory vesicle exocytosis, and is also responsible for neuro-muscular communication and the release of hormone from endocrine cells. Accurate modeling and deeper understanding of cell calcium signals that trigger neurotransmitter release and endocrine hormone release is at the core of the current project, and may provide deeper insight into the function of neural and endocrine systems both in the normal state and in pathological conditions, for instance type-II diabetes. This project will employ advanced mathematical and computational techniques in order to gain deeper knowledge of physiologically relevant cell calcium dynamics with high resolution in time and space. This will include further development of an open-source computational tool called CalC ("Calcium Calculator") for the simulation of three-dimensional cell calcium ion diffusion and calcium binding (http://www.calciumcalculator.org), contributing to the infrastructure for computational modeling in the biological sciences, facilitating rapid and effective dissemination of the obtained results through the publicly accessible on-line simulation file database. Students will be trained in the highly interdisciplinary field spanning applied mathematics, cell biophysics and computational neuroscience, contributing to the development of future researchers capable of using advanced computational methods to tackle problems of broad societal impact in the life sciences.

This project addresses several challenges in the modeling of cell calcium dynamics leading to neurotransmitter and hormone release. One of these challenges is taking into account the strong influence of various intracellular calcium-binding molecules, collectively termed calcium buffers and sensors, on cell calcium diffusion. This project extends recent studies of calcium diffusion in the presence of buffers with several calcium binding sites that bind calcium cooperatively through a mechanism similar to the process of cooperative binding of oxygen by hemoglobin. Cooperative binding distinguishes an important class of calcium buffer-sensors evolutionarily linked to calmodulin, and deeper understanding of their influence on calcium signals is important for the understanding of cell physiology.This project also explores the relationship between the two most widely used approaches in modeling calcium dynamics: the deterministic approach that models calcium as a continuous concentration distribution, and the stochastic approach that simulates trajectories of individual calcium ions and is assumed to be more realistic, but more expensive computationally. A novel analytical method will be applied to more accurately estimate stationary distribution of calcium near a single membrane calcium channel, allowing efficient modeling and analysis of calcium "nanodomains" that form around open calcium channels. Finally, through collaborative work with experimental physiologists, obtained methods and results will be applied to understand the interplay between calcium diffusion, buffering and sensing that underlies the observed dynamics of vesicle release in specific types of mammalian synapses and endocrine cells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

This Project was aimed at developing computational and mathematical modeling techniques for the study of calcium ion elevations inside biological cells. Understanding cell calcium dynamics is important since calcium regulates most vital physiological processes, from gene expression to muscle contraction. This Project focused on techniques used for the modeling of calcium-controlled vesicle membrane fusion, which underlies endocrine hormone release, synaptic neurotransmitter release, and immune system's T-cell response. This process is triggered when calcium ions enter the cell and bind to specialized proteins that fuse hormone-, neurotransmitter- or cytotoxin-containing vesicles with the outer cell membrane, allowing their contents to be released into the extracellular space and bind receptors of other cells. The complicating factor in the study of this mechanism is that calcium ions inside a cell are not evenly distributed but are highly localized, entering through membrane-spanning ion channels located close to the vesicles, and remain constrained within small regions termed "calcium nanodomains". Since these nanodomains are smaller than the wavelength of light, experimental microscopy techniques used to visualize this process remain inadequate. Therefore, computational and mathematical modeling methods explored in this Project play an important role in the understanding of secretory vesicle release and other processes controlled by localized elevations of cell calcium. The main goals and outcomes of this project concern the development of such mathematical modeling techniques:

1)  This Project resulted in the development of novel closed-form mathematical approximations for the dependence of calcium concentration on the distance from the calcium channel. Such closed-form approximations are very efficient and allow to avoid more computationally expensive simulations of calcium diffusion and binding in qualitative studies of calcium-dependent cell processes. These approximations also allow to understand in a simple and direct way how the spatial spread of local calcium elevations depends on the properties of calcium-binding substances called calcium buffers, which play an important role in regulating intracellular calcium concentration. The novelty of approximations developed in the course of this Project is that they are applicable to the case where the cell contains complex calcium buffers with multiple calcium binding sites, which are widely expressed in many cells, and which were not considered in prior mathematical work on calcium nanodomain approximations due to their complexity.

2)  This Project clarified the importance of random variations (fluctuations) in the number of calcium ions inside the cell for the modeling of secretory vesicle release. Evidence suggests that the number of calcium ions required for the release of a single neurotransmitter- or hormone-containing vesicle can be quite small. Therefore, random variations in the number of calcium ions at different locations inside the cell is expected to be quite large. However, mathematical modeling that takes into account such fluctuations is computationally expensive. Interestingly, this Project revealed that deterministic approaches based on so-called reaction-diffusion equations are quite accurate even when the number of calcium ions is low. The good performance of deterministic methods for the modeling of calcium dynamics was found to result from the small degree of correlation between fluctuations due to the calcium diffusion on the one hand, and fluctuations in calcium binding and unbinding on the other hand. These results are important for a full understanding of the effects of random fluctuations on biochemical cell processes, and can be used to guide the choice of the most efficient method for the modeling of a particular cell process.

3)  The computational tools developed in the course of this Project helped an international team of researchers gain new insights into the pathology of type-2 diabetes. Their joint work revealed that pancreatic insulin-releasing cells of tissue donors with this pathology exhibit properties that suggest a larger distance between insulin-containing vesicles and calcium channels, as compared to healthy cells. Therefore, it is possible that this disruption of vesicle-channel coupling may contribute to the pathology of type-2 diabetes. This work was published in the Journal of Clinical Investigation https://www.jci.org/articles/view/88491

Broader Impacts:

1)  This Project contributed to the computational modeling infrastructure in the broader areas of cell biophysics and computational neuroscience through the development of the modeling software tool called CalC ("Calcium Calculator"). CalC is an open-source software package made publically available by the PI of this Project (http://www.calciumcalculator.org), and is used by several laboratories throughout the word in the study of synaptic function, endocrine hormone release, and contraction of cardiac myocytes. Updates to the CalC software undertaken during the Project award period led to several new version releases, significantly increasing the features and computational efficiency of this modeling tool.

2)  This Project created student training opportunities in the highly interdisciplinary fields of applied mathematics, biophysics and computational neuroscience, contributing to the development of human resources that are able to combine advanced mathematical and computational skills with their knowledge of biology and physiology in tackling real-world problems of potential societal importance.
